results.title: First encounters
results.creator_credit: Ben Lewin, Karl McPhee, Malcolm Smith and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Migrant experience”.
Deals with the initial experience of various ethnic groups as they encounter Australia’s developing society and culture particularly the nature of the welcome experienced. Addresses what it is like to change cultural milieux, how forms of prejudice fit within Australian history and examines where attitudes towards migrants have changed.

results.title: Setting out
results.creator_credit: Ben Lewin, Malcolm Smith and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Migrant experience”.
Surveys the chief events in Australian and world history that have influenced our migration patterns and immigration laws. Notes Aboriginal migration to Australia, the First Fleet, the discovery of gold, the land boom, drought and depression in the 1890s, Federation, World War I and after, the 1930s depression, post-war immigration, multiculturalism and Asian immigration. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Are you fair dinkum?
results.creator_credit: Ben Lewin, Malcolm Smith and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Migrant experience”.
Looks at national identity and how the Australian way of life has been shaped by migration and the response of migrants to it. Shows the changes that have occurred as a result of the contributions of postwar migrants to Australian culture. Considers the role played by politics, the media and education.

results.title: Working
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Malcolm Smith, Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Migrant experience”.
Considers the roles migrants have played in the Australian labour force. Several historical aspects are dealt with through case studies, though the emphasis is on the nature and effect of the postwar migration boom. With work as one of the most significant points of interation between migrants and hosts, this episode examines the experience of both good and bad of the new work force.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karl McPhee, Malcolm Smith, Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs and Film Australia

results.title: South Africa belongs to us
results.creator_credit: Chris Austin, Westdeutscher Rundfunk and Gerhard Schmidt Produktion
results.brief_description: A film about black women in South Africa filmed secretly with the help of two black women journalists. Through interviews with five typical women, and comments from four women activists, including Winnie Mandela, the film clearly shows the devastating impact of apartheid on black women and their families. Narration by Peggy Phango.

results.title: Something old, something new
results.creator_credit: Ben Lewin, Karl McPhee, Malcolm Smith and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Migrant experience”.
Long-established and recent migrants describe the search for a personal balance between the old traditions and the new ways.

results.title: Sony Handycam DCR-SX65
results.brief_description: The Sony Handycam DCR-SX65 debuted in 1985 and while other models from the era have been discontinued, it’s been made in various formats ever since. Home videos might have been their original purpose, but camcorders like this have captured footage that has social and political ramifications.

constellations_primary.name: A handheld aesthetic
constellations_primary.description: Looking at the use of handycams and other consumer level devices in moving image works.

results.description: The Sony Handycam DCR-SX65 is what it says: it’s a handy camera. Debuting on the market in 1985, its name came from its compact size that allowed it to fit in the user’s hand and capture their everyday lives more easily. While other models from this era have been discontinued, the Sony Handycam DCR-SX65’s popularity has seen it made in various formats ever since. Home videos might have been their original purpose, but their cost and convivence meant camcorders like this have been used to capture amateur footage that has social and political ramifications all around the world.
description_for_label: The Sony Handycam DCR-SX65 is what it says: it’s a handy camera. Debuting on the market in 1985, its name came from its compact size that allowed it to fit in the user’s hand and capture their everyday lives more easily. While other models from this era have been discontinued, the Sony Handycam DCR-SX65’s popularity has seen it made in various formats ever since. Home videos might have been their original purpose, but their cost and convivence meant camcorders like this have been used to capture amateur footage that has social and political ramifications all around the world.

results.title: Soon there will be no more me
results.brief_description: Her daughter had just been born and Lyn Helton was still 19 years old when whe learned that she had a fatal type of cancer. In whatever time she had left, Lyn was determined to write a book of hope to be left to the world. Most of all it would be a way to communicate with her daughter who some day would want to know the mother she couldn’t remember. The soundtrack of the film consists of excerpts from Lyn’s unfinished book.
